newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel says reaches compromise with Buba over gold.
newsitem.headline: Waigel says reaches compromise with Buba over gold.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Tuesday he had reached a good compromise with the powerful central bank over his controversial plan to revalue their gold and currency reserves.
"It was a good compromise," Waigel told journalists after a meeting of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats (CDU) and Bavarian sister party the Christian Social Union (CSU) in Bonn.

Waigel said the deal, which coalition sources earlier said involved the government abandoning its plans to reap billions of marks (dollars) in quick cash profits from the Bundesbank in 1997, still had to be finalised with bank officials.
"It has to be negotiated. Central bank committees have to agree to it," Waigel said.
Asked whether Germany would fulfill the criteria for European economic and monetary union (EMU) in 1997 despite the lack of the windfall from the Bundesbank, Waigel said: "We will manage it in 1997."

Coalition sources said Bonn had agreed to accept the central bank's offer to transfer the funds in 1998, making it harder for Germany to qualify for Europe's single currency because Bonn badly needed the 10 billion marks from the plan in 1997.
